authorsByline: Jonathan Simmons | JSimmons@advance-ohio.com, Jonathan Simmons, jsimmons
title: ‘We spend to win’: Mike Gundy’s comments add fuel to Oregon-Oklahoma State showdown
description: Saturday's game takes on new edge after Gundy's $40M spending claim and Lanning's response about investing in championship-caliber teams.
content:
CLEVELAND, Ohio — Mike Gundy didn’t sound like he was trying to stir the pot, but stir it he did.

During his weekly radio show, the Oklahoma State head coach made a pointed comparison between his program’s NIL spending and what he believes Oregon is shelling out to build its roster.

“We’ve spent around $7 million over the last three years,” Gundy said. “I think Oregon spent close to $40 million last year alone. I might be off a few million, but the point is: they’re spending a lot. Some schools are doing that.”

Gundy went on to describe Oregon as one of college football’s financial powerhouses, long backed by Nike co-founder, and Ducks alumnus, Phil Knight.

He even name-dropped Ducks quarterback Dante Moore as an example of the kind of talent that requires serious investment to retain.

But Gundy’s comments weren’t just about Oregon — they were about the shifting landscape of college football. He expressed concern over how money is beginning to influence even non-conference scheduling.

“What I’m hearing from coaches around the country is that non-conference games should be scheduled based on financial parity,” Gundy said. “Oregon is paying a lot of money for their team. So some coaches think they should only play teams spending at a similar level.”

It’s a striking statement, especially considering Oklahoma State and Oregon agreed to this home-and-home series back in 2018, long before NIL and revenue-sharing changed the game.

When Oregon head coach Dan Lanning was asked about Gundy’s remarks, he didn’t shy away.

“I’ve got a ton of respect for Coach Gundy,” Lanning said. “But how blessed are we to be at a place that’s invested in winning? If you want to be a top-10 team, you better be invested. We spend to win. Some people save to have an excuse for why they don’t.”

Lanning also pointed to Oklahoma State’s Week 1 opponent, FCS program UT Martin, as a counter to the idea of matching schedules by budget.

“I don’t know what they’ve got in their pockets,” Lanning added. “But I’m sure UT Martin didn’t have as much as them last week, and they still played.”

Both teams enter Week 2 coming off wins against FCS opponents.

Oregon is once again in the College Football Playoff conversation, while Oklahoma State is looking to bounce back from its worst season under Gundy.

Now, with millions in spending and a few sharp words in the mix, Saturday’s matchup on CBS has a little extra edge.
summary: Oklahoma State football coach Mike Gundy's comments about comparing his program's spending to that of Oregon's, which he believes is spending significantly more on its roster. Gundy compared his team's $7 million over the last three years to Oregon's $40 million. He also expressed concern over how money is beginning to influence non-conference scheduling, suggesting that non-conference games should be scheduled based on financial parity. Oregon head coach Dan Lanning responded by saying he appreciated Gundy’s investment in winning, but also questioned the idea of matching schedules by budget. Both teams enter Week 2 coming off wins against FCS opponents.
shortSummary: Mike Gundy's comments on Oregon's extensive spending raise concerns about the influence of financial disparities on college football, particularly in upcoming matches between the sides.
argos_summary: Oklahoma State head coach Mike Gundy criticized Oregon’s large NIL spending, citing a $40 million outlay versus OSU’s $7 million over three years, and warned that money is reshaping non‑conference scheduling. He argued that teams should play opponents with similar financial parity. Oregon coach Dan Lanning countered that investment is essential for top‑10 contention, noting that even lower‑budget teams like UT Martin still compete. The comments add tension to the upcoming OSU‑Oregon series, highlighting the growing influence of money in college football.
